meanings.definition: Pronounced with a single sound or a combination of sounds forming a single unit of meaning.
meanings.sent1: The teacher explained the syllabled words clearly to the students.
meanings.sent2: The song had a catchy, syllabled chorus that everyone could sing along to.
meanings.sent3: The syllabled instructions on the board made the class burst into laughter.
meanings.sent4: Her syllabled laughter echoed through the room, filling it with joy.
meanings.sent5: The syllabled melody of the piano piece lingered in the air, enchanting all who listened.

meanings.definition: Having a specified number of syllables.
meanings.sent1: The poem had a beautifully syllabled rhythm that captivated the audience.
meanings.sent2: The syllabled name of the flower revealed its exotic origins.
meanings.sent3: The syllabled count of the haiku surprised the students in English class.
meanings.sent4: Her syllabled speech was so eloquent, it left everyone in awe.
meanings.sent5: The syllabled pattern of the song lyrics made it easy to remember and sing along.

meanings.sent1: She carefully syllabled the long word to make it easier to spell.
meanings.sent2: The teacher asked the students to syllable the word 'elephant' together.
meanings.sent3: As a joke, he syllabled his friend's name into silly sounds, making everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: The wind seemed to syllable the leaves as it rustled through the trees.
meanings.sent5: She tried to syllable the complex word, but it still sounded confusing to her ears.
